October 4, 2015: Fiction
MAKE ME, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) In his 20th appearance, Jack Reacher takes on
a missing-persons case.
THE GIRL IN THE SPIDER'S WEB, by David Lagercrantz. (Knopf.) Mikael Blomkvist
and Lisbeth Salander are back in this continuation of Stieg Larsson’s Millennium
series.
DEVOTED IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam.) Lt. Eve Dallas races the clock to
save a woman kidnapped by a couple on a murder spree; by Nora Roberts, writing
pseudonymously.
GO SET A WATCHMAN, by Harper Lee. (Harper.) In the mid-1950s, a grown-up Jean
Louise Finch returns home to find that her adored father is not as perfect as she
believed.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World War II.
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological thriller
set in the environs of London.
FATES AND FURIES, by Lauren Groff. (Riverhead.) A marriage viewed from two
perspectives.
X, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) A variety of X’s lead Kinsey Millhone onto
the trail of a cold case.
THE END GAME, by Catherine Coulter and J.T. Ellison. (Putnam.) The F.B.I. agent
Nicholas Drummond and his partner, Mike Caine, investigate a violent environmental
group with the help of the C.I.A. and Mossad.
THE SCAM, by Janet Evanovich and Lee Goldberg. (Bantam.) The F.B.I. agent Kate
O’Hare and her con man partner, Nicholas Fox, pose as gamblers in order to bring
down a casino magnate involved in money laundering.
PURITY, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) A recent college graduate,
a German Julian Assange-like activist, an investigative reporter and an heiress in
flight from her past strive for integrity and wrestle with secrets.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the Resistance
in Paris.
DRIVING HEAT, by Richard Castle. (Kingswell.) The N.Y.P.D. homicide detective
Nikki Heat attempts to stop a killer while her fiancé, the journalist Jameson Rook,
meddles in the case.
October 4, 2015
Non-Fiction
WHY NOT ME?, by Mindy Kaling. (Crown Archetype.) More personal essays from
the comedian and actress.
BETWEEN THE WORLD AND ME, by Ta-Nehisi Coates. (Spiegel & Grau.) A
meditation on race in America as well as a personal story by the national
correspondent of The Atlantic, framed as a letter to his teenage son.
THE ART OF MEMOIR, by Mary Karr. (Harper.) The author of “The Liars’ Club,”
“Cherry” and “Lit” offers instruction in memoir-writing and discusses her favorite
writers’ work.
FAST GIRL, by Suzy Favor Hamilton with Sarah Tomlinson. (Rey Street/Morrow.)
Bipolar disorder drove a former Olympic runner to become a high-priced Las
Vegas escort until she received treatment.
KILLING THE MESSENGER, by David Brock. (Twelve.) A former right-wing
operative describes his transformation and passionately defends Hillary Clinton.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
THE WRIGHT BROTHERS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster.) The story
of the bicycle mechanics from Ohio who ushered in the age of flight.
PLUNDER AND DECEIT, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-radio
host urges young Americans to resist the statist masterminds who, he says, are
burdening them with debt and inferior education.
ACCIDENTAL SAINTS, by Nadia Bolz-Weber. (Convergent.) A comic turned
pastor documents encounters with grace and finding divinity in unlikely places.
MODERN ROMANCE, by Aziz Ansari with Eric Klinenberg. (Penguin Press.) The
comedian enlists a sociologist to help him understand today’s dating scene.
EXCEPTIONAL, by Dick Cheney and Liz Cheney. (Threshold Editions.) The
former vice president and his daughter chart their vision for a formidable future
America.
DEAD WAKE, by Erik Larson. (Crown.) The last voyage of the Lusitania, the
passenger liner notoriously sunk by a German torpedo in 1915.
RECKLESS, by Chrissie Hynde. (Doubleday.) The Pretenders' frontwoman revisits
four decades in the music industry.
MY FIGHT/YOUR FIGHT, by Ronda Rousey with Maria Burns Ortiz. (Regan Arts.)
The U.F.C. women's bantamweight champion's struggles to succeed.
